instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi, got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B has green light, no turn on.  <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> are low. No signs of water damage. Only fan spin on SMC bypass. 

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = 5.1v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 5.1v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL>: 0.6v

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL> = 1.5v

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.5v

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> = 1.07v

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.05v

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4v"
Low, really???

"<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL>: 0.6v"
[U]There[/U] is the problem.

First compare diode mode reading on L7760 with good board.
If good, post <CHIP>U7760</CHIP> voltages.
Check <RESISTOR>R7760</RESISTOR>/61.
You may need to change the chip...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Diode mode readings on L7760 are good.

<RESISTOR>R7760</RESISTOR>/61 Good

Replaced <CHIP>U7760</CHIP> twice, now:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 0.6v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 0v

Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7800</TRANSISTOR> no change. 

<SIGNAL>P3V3_S4_EN</SIGNAL> is 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Which other voltages did you lose?
Re-check the job you've done.
Be sure didn't generate any short on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
With <CHIP>U7760</CHIP> removed the board quarter fans. Cleaned and replaced <CHIP>U7760</CHIP> again just in case, these are the voltages:


<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> =0v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 0.5v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 0v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0v

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL>: 0v

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL>: 0v

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>: 0v

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL>: 1.05v

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>: 0v


<TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR> looks good, <SIGNAL>P5V0S0_SS</SIGNAL> is not present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You had steady voltages before touching <CHIP>U7760</CHIP>; something happened then.
Check for short on all power rails.
Start with <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>1V8_S0</SIGNAL>.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Comparing diode mode with a good board in 0v power rails only <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is low (0.111 vs 0.402 on the good board)

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  is pulsing with <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> trigger

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> should pulse at same time; check that.
Also compare diode mode readings in opposite direction (black on ground).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
yes, <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> pulses with <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> trigger

Black on ground readings are 0.0l for both boards on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Other big coils pulsing?
Tested SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
L7630, L7100, L9701, L7330, L7260 pulse with <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> trigger

SCM bypass only makes fan spin for 1 sec

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check for pulse at pins 1, 2, 4 of <CHIP>U2650</CHIP>/60.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Only pin 2 of <CHIP>U2650</CHIP> pulsing with <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Really strange, are you sure?
That suppose pulsing CPU core, which requires <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> (as enable).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes. <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is also pulsing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Then what about <CHIP>U2660</CHIP>?
Please, post accurate information...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Sorry yes,

<CHIP>U2650</CHIP> pins 1 and 2 are pulsing for about 3v and pin 4 pulses for a few millivolts. 

<CHIP>U2660</CHIP> pins 1 and 4 are pulsing for a few millivolts and pin 2 for around 2v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulsing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Not pulsing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no turn on, low <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Check for pulse at voltages from page 22.
Pay atention to series resistors and coils.

Just in case, try known good BIOS.
